text: Atherosclerosis is a generalized process, often involving the entire arterial vasculature, and is inherent in the aging pro-ce~s.l-~ Although predominantly present in the abdominal aorta, atherosclerotic lesions are frequently seen in the thoracic a0m4 Previous studies have used roentgenography5 to identify calcific aortic atherosclerotic lesions with moderate success, and the presence of those lesions has been shown to be related to increased cardiovascular mortality: Recent improvements in ultrasound technology have allowed for detection of atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aortausing transesophageal imaging in the living population? A limited number of studies has shown that the discovery of atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta by use of transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) appears to be a marker for the presence of significant coronary artery disease (CAD) in the general population? while their absence rules out the possibility of coronary artery obstruction? Although many studies of the alteration of cardiovascular structure and function withm the aging process have been published,lOl 1 there are only a few studies, with contradictory results, concerning the relationship between atherosclerotic plaque in the thoracic aorta, as detected by TEE, and the presence of CAD in the elderly population. 12

The purpose of this study was to investigate whether the detection of atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta by TEE can be considered a clinically useful marker of significant CAD in patients, and in particular in those aged > 70 years.

The study population consisted of 127 patients (67 men, 60 women, mean age 68 k 13 years) who underwent TEE examination and were scheduled for coronary angiography. All patients gave informed consent. The reasons for performing TEE examination were valvular heart disease in 8 1 patients (64%) (37 with a prosthetic valve), endocarditis in 14 (1 l%), cerebrovascular stroke in 14 (1 1 %), aortic dissection in 8 (6%), left atrial myxoma in 3 (2%), and miscellaneous reasons in 7 patients (6%). The following risk factors for CAD were considered for each patient history: (1) Hypercholesterolemia, defined as a total cholesterol level > 200 mddl on two or more blood measurements; (2) diabetes mefitus, defined as hyperglycemiarequiring medication; and (3) arterial hypertension, defined as either systolic or diastolic blood pressure elevation requiring ongoing therapy.

Comprehensive transthoracic echocardiographic examination was performed initially in all patients and was followed by the transesophageal study. The equipment used was either a Toshiba SSH 350 A or 160A device (Toshiba Medical System, Crawley, U.K.) with a 2.5 and 3.75 MHz transducer for the transthoracic and a 5 MHz multiplane transducer for the transesophageal examination, or a Hewlett Packard Sonos 2500 device (Hewlett-Packard, Inc., Andover, Mass., USA). Pharyngeal anesthesia was achieved with lidocaine spray, and light intravenous sedation was given with midazolame (2 mg) in 106 patients and meperidine (10 mg) in all patients. After cardiac examination, the transducer was rotated posteriorly to obtain thoracic aortic images. Particular attention was paid to obtaining optimal echocardiographic images, using multiplane imaging from the ascending to the descending aorta. Blood pressure, heart rate, and electrocardiogram (ECG) were also monitored. All studies were recorded on super VHS videotape for subsequent review and analysis. The criterion used to diagnose atherosclerotic lesions was the presence of distinct, localized, highly echogenic masses protruding into the vessel lumen. Intra-aortic atherosclerotic lesions were graded on a scale of I to II as we have described previously9 (Fig. 1). Specifically, the thoracic aorta was considered normal, without atherosclerotic lesions, when the intimal surface was smooth and continuous without lumen irreg-ularities or increased echodensity. Focal or linear regions of increased echodensity, slightly elevated above the surface of the intima, were findings consistent with grade I. Grade I1 changes consisted of intimal thickening and lumen irregularities associated with echodense material that induced shadow artifacts and sometimes presented a degree of mobility. Echocardiographically visualized atherosclerotic lesions and their distribution within the entire thoracic aorta were classified by the investigator and reviewed by a second experienced observer who was blinded to the patient's history. Any discrepancy was solved by consensus.

Cardiac catheterization and coronary angiography were performed in all study patients. Significant coronary artery stenosis, detected by visual analysis, was defined as a 2 50% reduc- tion in the internal diameter of the main coronary artery or a 2 70% reduction in the internal diameter of the left anterior descending, right coronary, or left circumflex artery distribution.

Summary data are expressed as mean k standard deviation (SD) for continuous variables and as percentages for categorical variables. The analysis was stratified by age: one group of patients aged < 70 years and another aged 2 70 years. Chisquare or Fisher's exact tests were used to assess the strength of association between suspected risk factors and the presence of CAD in the two age groups. Covariates found to be significant in the univariate screen were then entered into a multivariate stepwise logistic regression model to identify variables containing independent diagnostic information for CAD. The thresholds for entry into and removal from the model were 5 and 10%. respectively.

Of 127 patients, 36 (28.3%) were found to have significant CAD determined by coronary angiography performed 1 day to 3 months after the echocardiographic study. Ten patients had single-vessel disease, 14 patients had double-vessel disease, and 12 patients had triple-vessel disease. No patient had left main coronary artery stenosis.

section_title: Atherosclerotic Lesions and Coronary Artery Disease
text: In the whole study sample, TEE detected atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta in 30 of 36 patients with CAD and in 20 of 91 without CAD. The sensitivity, specificity, and positive and negative predictive values of the method in detecting significant CAD were 83.3,78,60, and 92%, respectively, while the overall diagnostic accuracy was 79.5%. Of the 86 patients in the group < 70 years old (mean age 53 k 12 years), TEE revealed atherosclerotic lesions in 16 of 19 patients with CAD and in 7 of 67 patients without CAD. In this group, the sensitivity, specificity, and positive and negative predictive values of the method were 84.2, 89.6, 69.6, and 95.2%, respectively, while the overall accuracy was 88.5%. In the 41 patients aged 170 (mean age 75 k 4 years), atherosclerotic lesions were detected in 14 of 17 patients with CAD and in 13 of 24 patients without CAD. The sensitivity and specificity were now 82.4 and 46%, respectively; the positive and negative predictive values were 52 and 78.6%, respectively, while the overall accuracy of the method was 6 1 %. Transesophageal echocardiography detected atherosclerotic lesions in 8 of the 10 patients with single-vessel disease (SO%), in 12 of the 14 with double-vessel disease (85.7%), and in 10 of the 12 patients with triple-vessel disease (83.3%). The severity of the coronary artery stenosis, as expressed by the number of obstructed vessels, was not related to the extent of the aortic lesions.

Examination by TEE revealed atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta in 50 of 127 patients (39.3%). Aortic lesions were most frequently found in the descending aorta (56%) and in the arch (54%), while the ascending aorta was the least involved (16%). The sites in which atherosclerotic lesions appeared showed a similar distribution in patients over and under 70 years of age, as well as in those with or without CAD ( Table I). For patients < 70 years old, atherosclerotic lesions in the ascending aorta were found only in those who had coronary artery stenosis. Table LI shows the incidence of hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, the presence and grade of atherosclerotic plaque in the aorta, and the gender in all patients with CAD above or below 7 0 years of age.

section_title: Risk Factors and Aortic Lesions versus Coronary Artery Disease

text: Univariate analysis revealed that in patients < 70 years old the presence of atherosclerotic plaque in the thoracic aorta was a predictor for significant coronary artery stenosis (p < 0.00 I ) (Table ID). In the same group, hypertension (p < 0.00l) and the location of atherosclerotic lesions (p < 0.05) were significant predictors for CAD, while diabetes mellitus was of marginal significance (p < 0.08). In patients 2 70 years old, significant prognostic factors for CAD were grade I1 atherosclerotic plaque (p < 0.05) in the thoracic aorta, and gender (p = 0.07) to a lesser degree. Multivariate logistic regression analysis revealed that the presence of atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta, detected by TEE, were independent predictors for CAD in patients <70 years old (p<O.001), while diabetes mellitus was of marginal significance (p = 0.06). In patients 2 70 years old, the same analysis revealed that only the grade of atherosclerotic lesions was an independent predictor for significant coronary artery stenosis (p = 0.03).

section_title: Risk Factors versus Thoracic Aortic Plaque
text: Univariate analysis of risk factors for thoracic aorta atherosclerosis revealed that in patients aged < 70 years only hypertension was related to atherosclerotic lesions (p < 0.00 1), while in patients aged 270 years only diabetes mellitus was marginally related (p < 0.07) ( Table IV).

Since more than half of all deaths in the elderly are due to cardiovascular disease, it is of great importance to understand the physiologic changes that occur in the heart and in the blood vessels as a result of the aging process. Epidemiologic studies,14 based on a history of ischemic heart disease or on the resting ECG, have shown that the prevalence of CAD rises from 2 to 30% with increasing age. However, necropsy studies of elderly patients have found a 5040% prevalence of CAD, emphasizing the high incidence of undetected or latent CAD in this p0pu1ation.l~~ l6 Occult CAD can be diagnosed by applying a stress to the cardiovascular system. In patients who participated in the Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging,17 using the usual resting criteria, the prevalence of CAD varied between 13 and 22%. When stress criteria were added, either by a treadmill exercise stress or by an abnormal exercise thallium scan, the CAD prevalence doubled. l8 It is therefore apparent that the diagnosis of CAD in the older population is important and that care should be taken to rule it out even in asymptomatic individuals. Although the standard of reference for diagnosing significant CAD is coronary angiography, much attention has been given to establishing a safe, noninvasive method for the detection of CAD. Several studies have demonstrated that, as shown by chest x-ray, the early presence of calcified lesions in the thoracic aorta is independently associated with excess cardiovascular disease.6 However, the low resolution of x-ray studies limits the possibility of detecting atherosclerotic lesions in the aorta and drawing logical conclusions about the coexistence of CAD. Recent improvements in noninvasive imaging techniques, especially in ultrasound technology, have allowed for more reliable detection of atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta using a transesophageal approach, which offers high-resolution imaging for evaluation of diseases of the thoracic aorta. l9 In this study we found that the presence of atherosclerotic plaque in the thoracic aorta, detected by TEE, is a sensitive predictor of obstructive CAD in patients < 70 years old, while in patients 270 years of age it lacks sensitivity. Important, however, is that we found a high negative predictive value in both groups of patients, aged either < or 270 years. This means that the absence of atherosclerotic plaque in the thoracic aorta is a significant predictor of normal coronary arteries in all patients regardless of age. In practice, in patients aged 270 years, the presence of atherosclerotic plaque in the thoracic aorta, detected by TEE, failed to be an independent predictor of significant coronary artery stenosis, while in younger patients it was a strong predictor of CAD. Only a few studies have investigated the ability of TEE to predict CAD using the presence of atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta in the elderly population, and these have had conflicting results. Matsumura ef al. I2 showed that the detection of atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta by TEE is not useful in predicting significant CAD in elderly patients, but is a strong predictor in patients < 70 years. In contrast, Tribouilloy etaL21 found that aortic plaque is a significant independent predictor of significant CAD, even in patients 2 70 years old, although their patients had a higher overall inci-dence of CAD than did ours. Both these studies agree that the absence of atherosclerotic lesions is a powerful predictor of a lack of coronary artery stenosis. Fazio et al.22 also reported that detection of atherosclerotic plaque in the thoracic aorta by TEE showed high sensitivity and specificity for obstructive CAD; however, the significance of aortic plaque in elderly patients was not reported in detail. Of all additional risk factors we examined in patients < 70 years old, the presence of atherosclerotic plaque in the thoracic aorta (p<O.OOl) was an independent predictor for coronary artery stenosis, while diabetes mellitus was of marginal significance (p = 0.05); in patients 170 years old, the only independent predictor was the presence of grade I1 atherosclerotic lesions. It is interesting that hypertension was related to the presence of thoracic aorta atherosclerosis (p < 0.001) in patients aged < 70 years, while in patients aged 2 70 years only diabetes mellitus was related to a lesser degree (p = 0.07). These findings are in agreement with those of Khoury et al.* and Nishino et al. ,23 who found that hypertension and diabetes mellitus were significantly related to thoracic aorta atherosclerosis. However, both these studies referred to the general population and neither classified patients according to age.

Atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta are a good marker for the detection of coronary artery stenosis in patients < 70 years of age, but were less useful in the elderly patients (I 70 years) of our study. However, the absence of such lesions rules out the possibility of significant disease in all patients. These results should be taken into account for risk stratification in elderly, asymptomatic patients. Other modalities, such as stress tests, stress echocardiography, or pharmacologic thallium imaging, may be used when ischemic heart disease is suspected in patients aged I 7 0 years. Since age is a major risk factor for CAD, coronary angiography is usually performed in elderly patients scheduled for valve surgery. However, this is not always the case for younger patients, and TEE could serve as a screening examination for patients aged < 70 years. Even in older patients, though, the absence of aortic plaque on TEE could perhaps be added to the criteria for deciding not to perform coronary arteriography. Transesophageal echocardiography may also be helpful in avoiding complications when a patient is evaluated for angiography. Arterial embolism arising from aortic atherosclerotic lesions has been described as occurring spontaneously or following invasive procedures involving the aorta, such as catheterization or surgery.20

We did not examine other risk factors such as smoking or family history for CAD, but this was not the main aim of our study. It is possible that we have underestimated the incidence of atherosclerotic plaques on the upper portion of the ascend-ing aorta because of the interposition of the trachea; however, we believe that the use of the multiplane probe has reduced this inconvenience. Although the whole study sample was satisfactorily large, the group of patients I 70 years old was limited. A prospective study with a large group of elderly patients is needed to conf i r m our observations.

The transesophageal echocardiographic analysis of atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta can provide valuable information regarding the presence of significant CAD only in patients < 70 years old. However, in patients of all ages, the absence of atherosclerotic lesions in the thoracic aorta seems to be a specific marker for the absence of significant coronary artery stenosis; this information may be useful in the noninvasive assessment of elderly patients at risk of CAD.
